summary: This is an FBI Director's morning news briefing summarizing media coverage from September 13-16, 2019. It covers multiple topics including the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment investigation of President Trump, the DOJ Inspector General's report on FBI surveillance of Carter Page, legal cases involving Michael Flynn and Andrew McCabe, and various other Justice Department and FBI-related news. The briefing also mentions Harvard's investigation into donations from Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeff Sessions
persons.context: Former Attorney General whose testimony Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee were seeking in their impeachment investigation of President Trump.

persons.name: Charles J. Cooper
persons.context: Attorney who told committee staff that Sessions would need a subpoena to testify before the House Judiciary Committee.

persons.name: Jerrold Nadler
persons.context: House Judiciary Chairman who argued President Trump was enriching himself while in office and defended Democrats' impeachment efforts.

persons.name: Doug Collins
persons.context: Top Republican on the House Judiciary Committee who called for Inspector General Horowitz and FBI Director Wray to testify about the FISA report.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Attorney General who received the draft report from Inspector General Horowitz on FBI surveillance abuses.

persons.name: Michael Horowitz
persons.context: Inspector General who completed a draft report on the origins of the FBI's surveillance of Carter Page.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: FBI Director whom Rep. Doug Collins called to testify before the House Judiciary Committee about the FISA report.

persons.name: Robert Mueller
persons.context: Former special counsel who led the Russia investigation; the House Judiciary Committee sought grand jury material from his probe.

persons.name: Carter Page
persons.context: Former Trump campaign adviser who was surveilled by the FBI, subject of Inspector General Horowitz's report.

persons.name: Lindsey Graham
persons.context: Senate Judiciary Chairman who warned the FISA Court about being misled by the DOJ and FBI regarding Christopher Steele's dossier.

persons.name: Christopher Steele
persons.context: British ex-spy who compiled an unverified dossier on Trump that was used in FISA applications to surveil Carter Page.

persons.name: Trey Gowdy
persons.context: Former congressman and federal prosecutor who discussed the FISA report on Fox News with Sean Hannity.

persons.name: Sean Hannity
persons.context: Fox News host who interviewed Lindsey Graham and Trey Gowdy about the FISA investigation.

persons.name: Kevin McCarthy
persons.context: House Minority Leader who predicted former FBI leaders James Comey and Andrew McCabe would face criminal charges over FISA abuses.

persons.name: James Comey
persons.context: Former FBI Director whom Kevin McCarthy predicted would face criminal charges related to FISA abuses.

persons.name: Andrew McCabe
persons.context: Former acting FBI Director under investigation for allegedly lying to investigators; his lawyers sought information about grand jury proceedings.

persons.name: Michael Flynn
persons.context: Former National Security Adviser whose attorneys filed motions to obtain exculpatory evidence from the Mueller investigation.

persons.name: Emmet G. Sullivan
persons.context: Judge who issued a Brady order mandating prosecutors turn over exculpatory evidence to Michael Flynn's defense.

persons.name: Cynthia Shaw
persons.role: Director of DOJ Departmental Ethics Office
persons.context: DOJ ethics official who concluded Robert Mueller's reputation made it unlikely anyone would doubt his independence as special counsel.

persons.name: Eric Holder Jr.
persons.context: Former Attorney General who stated President Trump could be prosecuted by the next administration after leaving office.

persons.name: Jessie Liu
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia
persons.context: U.S. Attorney who received emails from Andrew McCabe's lawyer about grand jury proceedings in his case.

persons.name: Michael Bromwich
persons.context: Lawyer for Andrew McCabe who contacted prosecutors about media reports that a grand jury may have declined to indict McCabe.

persons.name: Josh Campbell
persons.context: CNN analyst and author of a book excerpt about the FBI briefing President-elect Trump on Russian election interference.

persons.name: Lawrence Bacow
persons.context: Harvard President who released investigation results showing Harvard accepted about $9 million in donations from Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Financier and convicted sex offender whose donations to Harvard University were investigated by the university.

persons.name: Brett Kavanaugh
persons.context: Supreme Court Justice who faced renewed sexual misconduct allegations from his time at Yale, defended by President Trump.

persons.name: Deborah Ramirez
persons.context: Yale classmate who accused Brett Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct during their college years.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: President who was subject of impeachment investigation and who defended Justice Brett Kavanaugh on Twitter.

connections.description: Sessions had a rocky relationship with Trump after recusing himself from the Russia investigation.
Chairman and ranking member of the House Judiciary Committee with opposing views on impeachment investigation.
Bromwich is McCabe's lawyer who contacted prosecutors about grand jury proceedings in McCabe's case.
Ramirez accused Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct during their time at Yale University.
Trump vigorously defended Kavanaugh on Twitter against renewed sexual misconduct allegations.
Graham appeared on Hannity's radio show to discuss the FISA investigation and Christopher Steele's credibility.
Horowitz submitted his draft report on FBI surveillance abuses to Attorney General Barr for review.

events.title: DOJ Rejects House Request for Mueller Grand Jury Material
events.description: The Justice Department pushed back against the House Judiciary Committee's request for secret grand jury material from the Mueller investigation, calling it a 'fishing expedition'.

events.title: DOJ IG Completes Draft Report on FBI Surveillance of Page
events.description: Inspector General Michael Horowitz completed a draft report on the origins of the FBI's surveillance of former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page.

events.title: Harvard Releases Epstein Donation Investigation
events.description: Harvard University President Lawrence Bacow released results showing Harvard accepted about $9 million from Jeffrey Epstein between 1998-2007.

events.title: Felicity Huffman Sentenced in College Admissions Scandal
events.description: Actress Felicity Huffman was sentenced to two weeks in prison for her involvement in the college admissions bribery scandal.

events.title: New York Times Publishes Kavanaugh Allegations
events.description: The New York Times published a report with new information about sexual misconduct allegations against Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh from his time at Yale.

events.title: Trump Defends Kavanaugh on Twitter
events.description: President Trump defended Justice Brett Kavanaugh in a series of tweets, accusing Democrats and media of trying to influence his opinions.

keyFacts: The House Judiciary Committee was seeking testimony from former Attorney General Jeff Sessions in their impeachment investigation of President Trump.
Justice Department Inspector General Michael Horowitz completed a draft report on the FBI's surveillance of Carter Page, reviewing over one million records and conducting over 100 interviews.
Harvard University accepted approximately $9 million in donations from Jeffrey Epstein between 1998 and 2007, according to an investigation released by the university.
President Trump vigorously defended Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh on Twitter after the New York Times published new allegations of sexual misconduct from his time at Yale.
The Justice Department rejected the House Judiciary Committee's request for grand jury material from the Mueller investigation, calling it a 'vague, overbroad fishing expedition'.
